title: Psalms Chapter 82 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 82 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 82 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 82.

questions.question: Who is standing in the congregation of the mighty according to Psalms 82:1?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:1 states, 'God standeth in the congregation of the mighty.'

questions.question: In Psalms 82:2, what is God asking about the judgment being given?
options: How long will ye judge unjustly?
questions.correctAnswer: How long will ye judge unjustly?
questions.explanation: The verse asks, 'How long will ye judge unjustly, and accept the persons of the wicked?'

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:3, whom are the judges commanded to defend?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and fatherless
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:3 says, 'Defend the poor and fatherless: do justice to the afflicted and needy.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 82:4 say should be done to the poor and needy?
options: Deliver them and rid them out of the hand of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Deliver them and rid them out of the hand of the wicked
questions.explanation: The verse commands, 'Deliver the poor and needy: rid them out of the hand of the wicked.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:5, how do the unjust judges walk?
questions.correctAnswer: On in darkness
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 states, 'They know not, neither will they understand; they walk on in darkness.'

questions.question: What does God say to the judges in Psalms 82:6?
options: Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High
questions.correctAnswer: Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'I have said, Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High.'

questions.question: What fate does Psalms 82:7 say awaits the judges despite being called gods?
options: Ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes
questions.correctAnswer: Ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:7 states, 'But ye shall die like men, and fall like one of the princes.'

questions.question: Who is called to arise and judge the earth in Psalms 82:8?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Arise, O God, judge the earth.'

questions.question: What will God inherit according to Psalms 82:8?
questions.correctAnswer: All nations
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:8 states, 'For thou shalt inherit all nations.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 82:3 commands to defend the rich and powerful.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:3 commands to 'Defend the poor and fatherless,' not the rich and powerful.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 82:5 says the foundations of the earth are orderly and stable.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 says, 'all the foundations of the earth are out of course,' indicating disorder.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 82:6 refers to the judges as children of the most High.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'all of you are children of the most High.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Psalms 82:2: 'How long will ye judge ______, and accept the persons of the wicked?'
questions.correctAnswer: unjustly
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:2 says, 'How long will ye judge unjustly...'

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:4, from whose hand should the poor and needy be delivered?
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked
questions.explanation: The verse commands to 'rid them out of the hand of the wicked.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:1, among whom does God judge?
questions.correctAnswer: Among the gods
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:1 states, 'he judgeth among the gods.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 82 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 82 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with feelings of injustice in their workplace. Based on Psalms 82, what biblical truth would you share about how God views unjust judgment?
options: God stands in the congregation of the mighty and judges among the gods.
God accepts the unjust judgments of the wicked.
God ignores the affairs of men.
God only judges in heaven, not among people.
questions.correctAnswer: God stands in the congregation of the mighty and judges among the gods.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:1 teaches that God stands in the assembly of the mighty and judges among the gods, showing that He actively judges injustice and expects righteous judgment.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82 instruct believers to respond to those who are poor and fatherless?
options: Defend the poor and fatherless and do justice to the afflicted and needy.
Ignore their plight because God will handle it.
Give them advice but do not get involved.
Leave them to the mercy of the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: Defend the poor and fatherless and do justice to the afflicted and needy.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:3 commands believers to defend the poor and fatherless and to do justice to those who are afflicted and needy, emphasizing practical acts of justice and care.

questions.question: In a church leadership meeting, a leader is accused of showing favoritism. What does Psalms 82 say about accepting the persons of the wicked?
options: It is condemned; leaders are called to judge justly without favoritism.
It is acceptable if it benefits the majority.
It is encouraged to keep peace.
questions.correctAnswer: It is condemned; leaders are called to judge justly without favoritism.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:2 rebukes unjust judgment and accepting the persons of the wicked, urging leaders to judge righteously and without partiality.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed by the darkness of their circumstances. How does Psalms 82 speak about walking in darkness and understanding?
options: Those who judge unjustly walk in darkness and lack understanding.
Walking in darkness is a sign of strong faith.
Understanding comes from ignoring worldly problems.
Darkness is an unavoidable part of life.
questions.correctAnswer: Those who judge unjustly walk in darkness and lack understanding.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 explains that unjust judges do not know or understand and walk in darkness, with foundations of the earth being out of course, indicating confusion and instability.

questions.question: What encouragement does Psalms 82 offer about the identity of those who have authority to judge, and how should that impact their conduct?
options: They are called gods and children of the Most High, so they must act justly.
They are ordinary people with no special status.
They are gods and can act however they want.
Their identity is irrelevant to their conduct.
questions.correctAnswer: They are called gods and children of the Most High, so they must act justly.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:6 declares that those in authority are called gods and children of the Most High, implying they have a divine responsibility to judge justly.

questions.question: A believer fears failure in leadership. What does Psalms 82 warn about the consequences of unjust judgment?
options: They shall die like men and fall like princes, losing their honor.
They will be rewarded despite injustice.
They will be promoted regardless of actions.
They will be protected from harm.
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die like men and fall like princes, losing their honor.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:7 warns that unjust judges, though called gods, will die like mere men and fall like princes, indicating the seriousness of their accountability.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82 encourage believers to pray for God's intervention in the world?
options: Arise, O God, judge the earth, for You shall inherit all nations.
Pray only for personal blessings and ignore the world.
Trust that humans alone will bring justice.
Avoid praying for the earth's judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: Arise, O God, judge the earth, for You shall inherit all nations.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:8 calls on God to arise and judge the earth, affirming that He is sovereign over all nations and will bring justice.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 82, God approves when the wicked receive favoritism in judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:2 clearly rebukes unjust judgment and the acceptance of persons of the wicked, showing that God does not approve favoritism toward the wicked.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 82 teaches that those in positions of authority who fail to judge justly are still considered gods without consequence.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: While Psalms 82:6 calls them gods, verse 7 warns they will die like men and fall like princes if they fail to judge justly, indicating consequences for unrighteousness.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 82 teaches us to ______ the poor and needy and rid them out of the hand of the wicked.
questions.correctAnswer: defend
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:4 urges believers to deliver the poor and needy and rescue them from the wicked, showing the biblical call to defend and help them.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82 remind believers about the foundation of justice and understanding in daily life?
options: When judges fail to understand, the foundations of the earth are out of course.
Justice is unimportant in the foundation of life.
Foundations are only physical, not spiritual.
questions.correctAnswer: When judges fail to understand, the foundations of the earth are out of course.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 explains that lack of knowledge and understanding leads to disorder, symbolized by foundations being out of course, highlighting the importance of wise judgment.

questions.question: A believer is called to serve in their local church. According to Psalms 82, what attitude should they have toward serving the afflicted and needy?
options: They should do justice and defend those in need.
They should serve only when convenient.
They should expect recognition for their service.
They should avoid involvement in others' problems.
questions.correctAnswer: They should do justice and defend those in need.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:3 instructs to defend the poor and fatherless and do justice to the afflicted and needy, encouraging active and just service within the community.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82 teach us about humility for those in authority?
options: Though called gods, they will die like men and fall like princes.
Their status makes them immune to consequences.
They should act as if they are untouchable.
questions.correctAnswer: Though called gods, they will die like men and fall like princes.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:6-7 teaches that despite their exalted status, leaders are mortal and accountable, reminding them to be humble and just.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 82, what is the ultimate hope for believers praying for justice in a world marked by injustice?
options: God will arise and judge the earth, inheriting all nations.
Justice will come only after this life.
Human effort alone will establish perfect justice.
questions.correctAnswer: God will arise and judge the earth, inheriting all nations.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:8 encourages believers to trust in God's sovereign judgment over the earth and all nations as the ultimate hope for justice.

questions.question: A Christian parent wants to teach their child about integrity. How can Psalms 82 inform this teaching?
options: Integrity requires just judgment and defending the needy, as God commands.
Integrity is only about personal success.
questions.correctAnswer: Integrity requires just judgment and defending the needy, as God commands.
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:2-4 emphasize just judgment and defending the afflicted and needy, which is foundational to integrity in life and leadership.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 82 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 82.

questions.question: In Psalms 82:1, God is described as standing in the congregation of whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The mighty
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:1 states that God standeth in the congregation of the mighty, indicating a divine assembly among powerful beings or judges.

questions.question: What is the primary charge God gives regarding judgment in Psalms 82:2?
options: Accept the persons of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Judge justly
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:2 rebukes unjust judgment and accepting persons of the wicked, emphasizing the need for justice.

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:3, whom are the judges commanded to defend?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and fatherless
questions.explanation: Verse 3 explicitly commands defending the poor and fatherless and doing justice to the afflicted and needy.

questions.question: Psalms 82:4 calls for delivering the poor and needy from what?
questions.correctAnswer: The hand of the wicked
questions.explanation: The verse specifically states to rid the poor and needy out of the hand of the wicked.

questions.question: What metaphor is used in Psalms 82:5 to describe the judges' lack of understanding?
questions.correctAnswer: Walking on in darkness
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 uses the metaphor of walking in darkness to depict ignorance and confusion of the judges.

questions.question: In Psalms 82:6, what term is used to describe the judges, indicating a divine or exalted status?
questions.correctAnswer: Gods
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'Ye are gods; and all of you are children of the most High,' highlighting a special status.

questions.question: What ultimate fate is predicted for the 'gods' in Psalms 82:7?
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die like men
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:7 warns that despite their exalted status, they shall die like men and fall like princes.

questions.question: Who is called upon to arise and judge the earth in Psalms 82:8?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Verse 8 calls upon God to arise and judge the earth, emphasizing His sovereign authority over nations.

questions.question: The phrase 'children of the most High' in Psalms 82:6 suggests what theological concept?
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sonship or delegated authority
questions.explanation: The phrase implies a special status granted by God, often interpreted as delegated divine authority among judges.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82:1-8 reflect a judicial or divine council motif common in the ancient Near East?
options: God presides over a divine assembly of lesser gods
The poor are excluded from council
questions.correctAnswer: God presides over a divine assembly of lesser gods
questions.explanation: The text mirrors the ancient Near Eastern motif of a divine council where God judges other divine beings or rulers.

questions.question: Which New Testament passage reflects the idea in Psalms 82:6 that 'ye are gods'?
questions.correctAnswer: John 10:34
questions.explanation: Jesus quotes Psalms 82:6 in John 10:34, defending His claim of being the Son of God and addressing accusations of blasphemy.

questions.question: Psalms 82:7’s warning that 'ye shall die like men' foreshadows what broader biblical theme?
options: Mortality of rulers despite divine status
questions.correctAnswer: Mortality of rulers despite divine status
questions.explanation: It highlights the theme that earthly or even divine-like rulers are subject to death, underscoring human limitations.

questions.question: The repeated call to defend the poor and needy in Psalms 82:3-4 emphasizes which biblical justice principle?
options: Social responsibility and protection of the vulnerable
questions.correctAnswer: Social responsibility and protection of the vulnerable
questions.explanation: The psalm stresses that justice involves active defense and delivery of the afflicted and needy from oppression.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 82 depicts the 'gods' as perfect and infallible rulers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:5 highlights their ignorance and failure in judgment, indicating imperfection.

questions.question: The term 'Selah' in Psalms 82:2 likely serves what literary function?
questions.correctAnswer: Pause for contemplation
questions.explanation: 'Selah' is used in Psalms as a musical or liturgical pause inviting reflection on the preceding statement.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 82 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 82 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: In Psalms 82:1, where is God said to stand and what is His role among the 'gods'?
options: God stands in the congregation of the mighty and judges among the gods
God stands alone on a mountain judging the nations
God sits in heaven judging angels only
God walks among the people and forgives their sins
questions.correctAnswer: God stands in the congregation of the mighty and judges among the gods
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:1 explicitly states that God stands in the congregation of the mighty and judges among the gods, indicating His supreme judicial authority over lesser divine beings or rulers. This theme aligns with passages like John 5:22, where God the Father has given all judgment to the Son, and Romans 13:1 about authorities being established by God.

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:2, what unjust behavior is God condemning among the judges or rulers?
options: Judging unjustly and accepting the persons of the wicked
questions.correctAnswer: Judging unjustly and accepting the persons of the wicked
questions.explanation: The verse condemns partiality and injustice in judgment, which violates God’s holiness and justice (Deuteronomy 1:17; Proverbs 24:23-25). God's rebuke emphasizes that rulers must judge fairly without favoritism, reflecting His righteous character (James 2:1-4).

questions.question: Which groups are the rulers instructed to defend and do justice for in Psalms 82:3?
questions.correctAnswer: The poor and fatherless
questions.explanation: Psalms 82:3 calls for defense of the poor and fatherless, emphasizing God's concern for the marginalized, consistent with Exodus 22:22-24 and James 1:27, which instruct believers to protect widows and orphans as an expression of true religion.

questions.question: Psalms 82:4 commands deliverance from whom?
questions.correctAnswer: The wicked
questions.explanation: The verse instructs delivering the poor and needy from the hand of the wicked, highlighting God's justice against oppression. This mirrors themes in Isaiah 1:17 and Proverbs 31:8-9 about rescuing those unjustly treated.

questions.question: What is said about the understanding and knowledge of the judges in Psalms 82:5?
options: They know not, neither will they understand; they walk on in darkness
They are wise and enlightened by God’s Spirit
They rule with mercy and kindness
questions.correctAnswer: They know not, neither will they understand; they walk on in darkness
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the spiritual blindness and ignorance of these judges, who lack true understanding, paralleling Isaiah 59:10 and 2 Corinthians 4:4 which speak of darkness over the minds of those who reject God’s truth.

questions.question: According to Psalms 82:6, what are the judges called, and what is their relationship to the Most High?
options: They are called gods and are children of the Most High
They are prophets and servants of the Lord
They are angels and ministers of God
questions.correctAnswer: They are called gods and are children of the Most High
questions.explanation: This verse uses the term 'gods' metaphorically for earthly rulers who bear divine authority but are still accountable to God. This aligns with John 10:34-36 where Jesus references this passage to defend His divine claims and highlights humans’ role as God's representatives.

questions.question: What is the fate of these 'gods' as stated in Psalms 82:7?
options: They shall die like men and fall like princes
They shall be exalted among the nations
They shall be saved by God's mercy
questions.correctAnswer: They shall die like men and fall like princes
questions.explanation: Despite their exalted title, these rulers will experience mortality and judgment just like humans, showing that divine status does not exempt from death. Hebrews 2:14-15 and Ecclesiastes 3:20 reflect on the mortality of all mankind including rulers.

questions.question: What is the plea to God in Psalms 82:8, and what is the reason given?
options: Arise, O God, judge the earth: for thou shalt inherit all nations
Bless the people and provide peace
Send a deliverer to save Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Arise, O God, judge the earth: for thou shalt inherit all nations
questions.explanation: The psalm ends with a call for God’s righteous judgment over all the earth, affirming His sovereign right to rule all nations. This is consistent with Psalm 2:8-9 and Revelation 11:15 where God’s universal kingship is proclaimed.

questions.question: What theological truth about divine justice is emphasized by God's judgment among the gods in Psalms 82:1?
options: God is the supreme judge over all earthly and spiritual authorities
God only judges humans and not spiritual beings
God shares judgment equally with other gods
God delegates all judgment to angels
questions.correctAnswer: God is the supreme judge over all earthly and spiritual authorities
questions.explanation: The text portrays God as the ultimate judicial authority even over beings referred to as 'gods,' which could denote earthly rulers or spiritual beings, affirming His supremacy (Daniel 7:9-10, Psalm 96:10, Matthew 25:31-32).

questions.question: How does Psalms 82:3-4 reflect God's concern for social justice?
options: By commanding defense and deliverance of the poor and needy from oppression
By requiring sacrifices to atone for social sins
By commanding kings to build great cities
By focusing on the wealth of the nation
questions.correctAnswer: By commanding defense and deliverance of the poor and needy from oppression
questions.explanation: These verses emphasize God's call for justice that protects vulnerable groups, consistent with Isaiah 58:6-7 and Micah 6:8 which define true worship as caring for the oppressed.

questions.question: What does the phrase 'all the foundations of the earth are out of course' in Psalms 82:5 imply about the state of justice?
options: The moral and judicial order of the world is disrupted due to unjust judges
The kings have united in peace
The earth is awaiting the Messiah
questions.correctAnswer: The moral and judicial order of the world is disrupted due to unjust judges
questions.explanation: This indicates a cosmic disorder resulting from unrighteous leadership, paralleling Isaiah 24:18-20 and Proverbs 11:1 which describe societal collapse when justice fails.

questions.question: What does Psalms 82:6 teach about the nature of those called 'gods' and their accountability?
options: Though called gods, they are still mortal and accountable to the Most High
They are immortal beings with no accountability
They are false gods worshipped by the people
They are angels who serve God faithfully
questions.correctAnswer: Though called gods, they are still mortal and accountable to the Most High
questions.explanation: The term 'gods' refers to human rulers endowed with authority but subject to death and divine judgment, underscoring accountability as seen in Ecclesiastes 5:8 and Romans 13:1-2.

questions.question: How does Psalms 82:7 relate to Christian eschatology regarding judgment and resurrection?
options: It predicts the death of rulers but implies future resurrection and judgment
It promises rulers eternal life without judgment
It denies any judgment for kings
It foretells the eternal reign of human judges
questions.correctAnswer: It predicts the death of rulers but implies future resurrection and judgment
questions.explanation: The verse acknowledges human mortality but within biblical eschatology, death is followed by resurrection and final judgment (Daniel 12:2; John 5:28-29; Revelation 20:12), reflecting the ultimate accountability of all.

questions.question: What is the significance of the command 'Arise, O God, judge the earth' in Psalms 82:8 for understanding God’s kingship?
options: It affirms God's active and universal role as sovereign judge over all nations
It requests God to establish a new temple
It asks God to destroy the earth
It calls for God to remain silent
questions.correctAnswer: It affirms God's active and universal role as sovereign judge over all nations
questions.explanation: This plea emphasizes God’s universal sovereignty and just rule, consistent with Psalm 96:10, Isaiah 33:22, and Revelation 19:11 where God's righteous judgment and kingship are prominent themes.

questions.question: What doctrinal truth about human authority is taught by the designation 'children of the Most High' in Psalms 82:6?
options: Human rulers derive their authority from God and bear His image
Human rulers are divine beings equal to God
Human rulers are independent of God
Human rulers are angels in disguise
questions.correctAnswer: Human rulers derive their authority from God and bear His image
questions.explanation: Being called children of the Most High indicates that earthly authority is granted by God and reflects His image (Genesis 1:26-27; Romans 13:1), but does not confer deity, highlighting responsibility and accountability.
